user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BinSemCreate:
```c
int32 OS_BinSemCreate(osal_id_t *sem_id, const char *sem_name, uint32 sem_initial_value, uint32 options)
{
    int32                         return_code;
    OS_object_token_t             token;
    OS_bin_sem_internal_record_t *binsem;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(sem_name);

    /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        binsem = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_bin_sem_table, token);

        /* Reset the table entry and save the name */
        OS_OBJECT_INIT(token, binsem, obj_name, sem_name);

        /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  This reads info from the table. */
        return_code = OS_BinSemCreate_Impl(&token, sem_initial_value, options);

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sem_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct calls to standard <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) appear in the visible code. The remaining lines (variable declarations, OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_id), the call to OS_BinSemCreate_Impl, OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew, and the final return) do not themselves perform string handling and thus do not need investigation for Rule 21.17. The three reported fragments are macro or function invocations that take the sem_name string as an argument (or save the name) and therefore could internally invoke string.h routines or perform copies that might access beyond object bounds; they should be inspected. No other fragments in the provided code reference string pointer parameters or are likely to involve standard string handling.
